page.title: 04PAN HA'
page.content: PAN HA' is owned by the National Trust who took it over in 1968. The houses were in ruins and numbers two to six were completely rebuilt. The completed project was opened by the Queen Mother (Elizabeth - consort of George VI) in 1969. Pan Ha' consists of twelve houses in a row with another house stepped back from them. It is split into two flats and has a date on it - 1582. Its name is 'The Anchorage'. Pan Ha' gets its name from the salt pans that were used for making salt in the area. Ha' comes from haugh meaning a flat piece of land beside the sea, which Pan Ha' is. The houses are white with crow stepped gables and the new houses have bigger windows than the old. The first house, which used to be a wash house, is so old that its door is more than a meter below present ground level.
